messageBody:
Anthony Grahn scripsit:

> Here's my main objection in a nutshell:

Fear not.

> - Kingsley spells "path" with #32 Ah and "as" with #30 At
>
> - Most Americans spell both "path" and "as" with #30 At
>
> If we must all now use #32 for the word "path" while still using
> #30 for "as" it would be problem enough.

I agree, and I would never advocate doing that. If we think of this
case in terms of the lexical sets, we see how it works. The sets
are BATH, TRAP, and PALM. Some dialects merge BATH with TRAP (most
Americans, Australians), others merge BATH with PALM (RP, NZ). So
those who have the first merger write #30 At in BATH words, and those
who have the second merger write #32 Ah in the same words. Fortunately,
no dialect uses three different sounds for the different sets.

> Now if we let Americans use #30 for the word "path" then we must
> let Tasmanians use #28 if they want. I have observed that this creates
> no difficulties in practice and we will still all be able to read
> their towering body of literature without difficulty.

Quite so.

--
Not to perambulate John Cowan <cowan@...>
